abstract: Saudi Arabia's justice system, object of global criticism for its opaqueness and cruelty, has series of internal checks and paths to mercy that remain poorly understood by outside world; while some punishments like beheading for murder are mandated under centuries-old Shariah law, judges enjoy significant autonomy to grant clemency for many crimes that are not so strictly defined.
lead_paragraph: A confessed murderer’s life was spared because of little-known checks in a judicial system regularly condemned by human rights groups.

headline.main: Saudi Justice, Harsh but Able to Spare the Sword
headline.print_headline: Saudi Justice, Harsh but Able to Spare Sword

snippet: A confessed murderer’s life was spared because of little-known checks in a judicial system regularly condemned by human rights groups.
